text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
MATERIAL CHANGES
Revised IRM 8.7.17.4 (2) Note, Preparing Remittance Packages for Mailing, to indicate that personally identiﬁable information (PII) or sensitive but unclassiﬁed (SBU) information should not
Revised IRM 8.7.17.5.1 (1), Determining Whether Remittance is a Payment or IRC 6603 Deposit, to clarify deposit procedures.

Revised IRM 8.7.17.5.3 (1) a, IRC 6603 Deposits Received Prior to Issuance of Notice of to clarify when the tax, for a timely petitioned Tax Court case, will be assessed per Rev. Proc. 2005-18, Section 4.02.
IRM 8.7.17.5.3 (2) Note, IRC 6603 Deposits Received Prior to Issuance of Notice of to IRM 8.7.17.6 (3), Application of Undesignated Remittances.

Added new IRM 8.7.17.10, Processing Time-Value-of-Money-Remittances, that contains information for processing tax-value-of-money remittances in accordance with Revenue Procedure 2002-18 for a change in accounting method issue.
Revised, clariﬁed, and reorganized information throughout this IRM section. Also, updated IRM references and links.
AUDIENCE
Appeals

) Purpose: This IRM section provides information on processing remittances received by Appeals. Speciﬁcally, IRM

: a. Describes the Appeals Technical Employee’s (ATE) responsibilities upon receipt of a remittance b. Provides the time frames for processing remittances c. Describes the steps to identify the type of remittance, prepare forms, and ship payments to Submission Processing Centers d. Explains how remittances are applied in certain situations e. Identiﬁes circumstances that require different procedures and includes links to IRM subsections containing those procedures f. Recommends resources, including websites, Internal Revenue Code (IRC) Section references, a Revenue Procedure, and other IRM sections (
) Audience: Appeals employees that handle remittances, including ATEs and Appeals employees that assist the ATE in preparing remittances for and shipment, such as Case Processors (
) Policy Owner: Director, Case and Operations Support (
) Program Owner: Director, Policy, Planning, Quality, and Analysis (

) Contact Information: Appeals employees should follow established on How to Contact an Analyst. Other employees should contact the Product Content Owner shown on the Product Catalog Information page for this IRM Section. (

) Appeals’ mission is to resolve Federal tax controversies without litigation on a basis which is fair and impartial to both the Government and the taxpayer, promotes a consistent application and interpretation of, and voluntary compli- ance with, the Federal tax laws, and enhances public conﬁdence in the integrity and efficiency of the Internal Revenue Service. See IRC

) , Purposes and Duties of Office. Appeals accomplishes this mission by ing protested and Tax Court cases and negotiating settlements in a manner which ensures Appeals employees act in accord with the Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR) in every interaction with taxpayers. See IRC
), Execution of Duties in Accord with Taxpayer Rights, Pub
, Taxpayer Bill Rights, and IRM
, Accomplishing the Appeals Mission. (
) IRM
, Remittance Policy, provides Service-wide policy on processing remittances received in IRS ﬁeld offices. The Service is committed to a
hour deposit standard that applies to all remittances collected. The is for remittances collected in ﬁeld offices to be processed on the day of receipt or by the next business day. See IRM
Hour Deposit Standard, and IRM
, Cash Management Responsibilities. (
) ATEs should solicit payment upon reaching a conclusion in a case. See IRM
), Reaching a Conclusion in the Case. Upon receipt of any the ATE must follow the procedures in this IRM Section to ensure timely deposit and proper identiﬁcation and posting of the payment. (
) IRC
, Deposit of Collections, provides a general rule for daily depositing taxes and revenues received under the instructions of the Secretary. IRM
, Deposit Activity, contains instructions for remitting payments to the IRS location for deposits to be made within
hours of IRS’ receipt. Internal Revenue Manual
Purpose: This IRM section provides information on processing remittances received by Appeals. Speciﬁcally, IRM 8.7.17:

Describes the Appeals Technical Employee’s (ATE) responsibilities upon receipt of a remittance Provides the time frames for processing remittances Describes the steps to identify the type of remittance, prepare forms, and ship payments to Submission Processing Centers Explains how remittances are applied in certain situations Identiﬁes circumstances that require different procedures and includes links to IRM subsections containing those procedures Recommends resources, including websites, Internal Revenue Code (IRC) Section references, a Revenue Procedure, and other IRM sections

IRC 7809, Deposit of Collections, provides a general rule for daily depositing of taxes and revenues received under the instructions of the Secretary. IRM 3.8, Deposit Activity, contains instructions for remitting payments to the appropriate IRS location for deposits to be made within 24 hours of IRS’ receipt.
8.7 Technical and Procedural Guidelines

IRC 6603, Deposits Made to Suspend Running of Interest on Potential Under- payments, etc., allows a taxpayer to designate payments as “deposits”. Unique provisions apply to these deposits as discussed in IRM 8.7.17.6, Application of Undesignated Remittances.

(4) Additional resources and job aids include:

The Electronic Federal Tax Payment System (EFTPS) processes electronic remittances listed in IRM 3.17.277.2.4, EFTPS Payment Methods. Remittances through EFTPS are not subject to the procedures in this IRM Section.

8.7 Technical and Procedural Guidelines

) The Appeals Technical Employee (ATE) will encourage the taxpayer to pay total tax, penalty and interest due on agreed deﬁciency cases. This will the taxpayer’s overall cost. Because Appeals does not have a teller function, cash payments cannot be accepted. Taxpayers who want to pay in cash to convert the cash into a postal money order, bank cashier’s check, money order or some other negotiable instrument. If the taxpayer is unable to pay deﬁciency in full, discuss alternatives such as installment agreements or in-compromise. (

) A successful criminal investigation or prosecution may be imperiled by the receipt and disposition of advance payments on a case with criminal fraud plications. Prior to processing the payment, consult with Counsel on an expedited basis. Appeals will not notify the taxpayer of the receipt or disposi- tion of the remittances. ) The request to designate all or part of the remittance to “interest” is honored one of the following conditions is met: a. The taxpayer agrees to assessment by executing a waiver of or b. ) Appeals employees will send all remittances via overnight service to City Submission Processing Center. However, an Appeals office located in same building as a Submission Processing Center can continue to hand remittances for processing to the Field Office Payment Processing Unit to overnight mailing costs. (

Appeals employees will send all remittances via overnight service to Kansas City Submission Processing Center. However, an Appeals office located in the same building as a Submission Processing Center can continue to hand carry remittances for processing to the Field Office Payment Processing Unit to overnight mailing costs.

) Sending offices must establish a control to ensure delivery of tax receipts during transit, and follow-up timely. The control must include amounts of taxpayer receipts, listed separately, and taxpayer identiﬁcation numbers that are correlated to the package tracer information. (

) The Appeals Technical Employee (ATE) must determine whether a is a deposit or a payment of tax. Both types of remittances will be posted a taxpayer’s account as of the date of receipt, and both will stop the running interest on a deﬁciency from the date the remittance is received. See IRM
, Determining Whether Remittance is a Payment or IRC
Deposit. (
) Per IRC
, a taxpayer may make a cash deposit with IRS which can be used to pay any income, estate, gift, or excise tax (under Chapter
, or
) that has not been assessed at the time of the deposit. Deposits are potential payments towards potential underpayments. To the extent that the deposit is used by IRS to pay tax, for purposes of IRC
(relating to interest on underpayments), the tax should be treated as paid when the deposit is made. (
) Rev. Proc.
refers to remittances designated as deposits as “desig- nated remittances” and remittances that are not designated as deposits as “undesignated remittances”. (

) After determining the remittance is a payment of tax (not a deposit), the must then determine if the payment is an advance payment on a (i.e. before the tax assessment) or subsequent payment (i.e. after the tax sessment). Advance payments are deﬁned as payments, not IRC
deposits, that are intended for application to anticipated, pending, or deﬁciencies or additional assessments. (
) Prepare Form
-A, Payment Posting Voucher - Examination, for “advance payments” and “IRC
deposits”. See IRM
, Preparing Forms
-A and
Note: For subsequent payments (i.e. payments after liability assessment), Form
-A or Form
, Payment Posting Voucher. (

Per IRC 6603, Deposits Made to Suspend Running of Interest on Potential Un- derpayments, a taxpayer may make a cash deposit with the Secretary with respect to a tax that has not been assessed at the time of the deposit. Rev. Proc. 2005-18, 2005-13 IRB 798, provides guidance on IRC 6603. For a remit- tance to be treated as an IRC 6603 deposit, the remittance must be accompanied by a written statement designating it as an IRC 6603 deposit. The statement must identify the:

Interest will continue to accrue on accrued interest. order to stop the running of any further interest, a taxpayer must make a tance sufficient to cover all accrued interest as of the date of remittance as well as the entire amount of the underlying tax and penalty (if applicable). (

) A taxpayer may request the return of all or part of a deposit at any time the Service has applied the deposit as a “payment of tax”. The deposit will be returned to the taxpayer upon receipt of a written request, unless collection the tax is determined to be in jeopardy. For more information, see Section
Rev. Proc.

, Honoring Request for Return of Deposits.

This transaction code is used even though the remit- tance is a deposit, not an advance payment. See IRM

, Identifying Deposits on Transcripts. Interest will continue to accrue on accrued interest. In order to stop the running of any further interest, a taxpayer must make a remit- tance sufficient to cover all accrued interest as of the date of remittance as well as the entire amount of the underlying tax and penalty (if applicable).

) A taxpayer may request the return of all or part of a deposit at any time before the Service has applied the deposit as a “payment of tax”. The deposit will be returned to the taxpayer upon receipt of a written request, unless collection of the tax is determined to be in jeopardy. For more information, see Section
of Rev. Proc.
Also, see IRM
, Honoring Request for Return of Deposits.

Advance payments made on processed returns are treated as credits, and ad- ditional steps must be taken to have the tax assessed. Ordinarily, if a nondocketed case is closed promptly and the advance payment is equal to or less than the proposed deﬁciency and interest, Account Processing and Support (APS) will assess the liability when they close the case. However, in all docketed cases and in nondocketed cases where closing will be delayed, or where the payment might exceed the tax due, the liability will be assessed promptly. In such cases, the ATE will prepare instructions on the Form
directing the assessment of the liability for the advance payment.
Technical and Procedural (

) Once the taxpayer, who made a deposit, agrees to the full amount of the proposed deﬁciency, the liability is assessed. The deposit is applied against Under assessed liability as a payment of tax as of the assessment date. See Section (Cash
) of Rev. Proc.

) A taxpayer can have any part of a deposit that exceeds the amount of tax as liability applied against another assessed or unassessed liability. For example, the taxpayer under examination can request that a deposit made for one type of tax in one year be applied to another type of tax in another year. The request must be in writing and must be directed to the same office where the original deposit was made. When any excess deposit is moved, it will be con- sidered a deposit as of the date it is moved. See Section
) of Rev.
) If the taxpayer has not signed an agreement form but has submitted a remit- tance without speciﬁcally addressing how to apply the remittance, the ATE must still process the payment within
hours. If necessary, the Designated Payment Code (DPC) can be changed at a later date by completing and for- warding Form
, Account Adjustment Voucher, to the address previously used for the remittance and payment posting voucher. (

) Undesignated (those not designated as a deposit) voluntary payments are treated as payments and are applied by the Service against any outstanding liabilities, unless one of the exceptions described in sections

applies. Per Rev. Proc.

, the Service apply undesignated payments to periods in the order of priority that the determines will serve its best interest. If a payment is not speciﬁcally desig- nated, allocate the payment to the earliest unpaid and collectible liability owed and due as of the payment availability date, i.e. oldest open Collection Statute Expiration Date (CSED) in the order - tax, penalty and interest. Also, see IRM
, Application of Payments. (
) The undesignated remittance treated as a payment is considered when deter- mining the existence of a deﬁciency and whether a notice of deﬁciency is required to be issued. See section
of Rev. Proc.

An “undesig- nated remittance” made after the mailing of a notice of deﬁciency will be considered a payment of tax, will be posted to the taxpayer’s account as soon as possible, and will not deprive the Tax Court of jurisdiction over the deﬁ- ciency (

) Except in a case where IRS determines that collection of tax is in jeopardy, IRS can return to the taxpayer any amount of the deposit (to the extent not used for payment of tax) which the taxpayer requests in writing. See IRC
(c), Return of Deposit. Deposits will be treated as used for the payment the tax in the order deposited [i.e. last-in, ﬁrst-out (LIFO) basis], except as otherwise provided by the taxpayer. See IRC
(e), Use of Deposits. (

8.7 Technical and Procedural Guidelines
Remittance Procedures 8.7.17

IRC 6603 deposits will be posted to a taxpayer’s account as of the date of receipt and will stop the running of interest on a deﬁciency from the date the remittance is received. Deposits are potential payments towards potential underpayments. The tax will be treated as paid on the date of deposit to the extent the deposit is used by IRS to pay the tax. See IRC 6603(b), No Interest Imposed.
(4) Overpayment Interest (IRC 6611)

A deposit which is returned to a taxpayer will be treated as a payment of tax for any period to the extent (and only to the extent) attributable to the disputable tax for such period. The overpayment interest will be the Federal short-term rate mined under IRC 6621(b), compounded daily. See IRC 6603(d), Payment of Interest. Rules similar to the rules of IRC 6611(b)(2) will apply. For additional infor- mation, see the following in IRM 20.2.4, Overpayment Interest

) A Lockbox is a non-IRS facility. Generally, it is a commercial bank that and processes payments only from taxpayers or tax professionals for Intended for form types. This method of processing payments serves to accelerate the handling and deposit of funds received and forwarded to Treasury. (
) A Lockbox does not acknowledge Form
or process Form
or

-A. Payments sent directly to a Lockbox by an IRS office are generally forwarded to a Submission Processing center for processing, delaying the posting of the payment to the taxpayer’s account. As a result, the taxpayer may incur penalty and interest that will later need to be corrected. (
) Payments intended for Lockboxes that are received by Appeals should be processed as indicated in IRM
, Preparing Forms
-A and and IRM
, Preparing Remittances Packages for Mailing.
For additional information, see IRC 6603, Deposits Made to Suspend Running of Interest on Potential Underpayments, Etc..

Payments intended for Lockboxes that are received by Appeals should be processed as indicated in IRM 8.7.17.3.1, Preparing Forms 3244-A and and IRM 8.7.17.4, Preparing Remittances Packages for Mailing.

), authorizes Appeals or Counsel to a “change in accounting method issue” by agreeing that the taxpayer will the government a “speciﬁed amount” that approximates the time-value-of- money (TVM) beneﬁt the taxpayer has derived from using its method of accounting for the taxable years before Appeals or a federal court (instead of the method of accounting determined by Appeals or Counsel to be the method of accounting), reduced by an appropriate factor to reﬂect the of litigation. If Appeals resolves this issue as a TVM resolution, the TVM lution amount (i.e. the “speciﬁed amount”) is not assessed.
